### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:How do you indicate that you agree wtih someone? Choices:  A. house-move-so that-bed-room  B. house-move- so-many-bed-room  C. house-move-bedroom -so-that  D. house-move-we-all-bedrooms E. house-move-people-bedrooms<n>Output: 1). The prepositions'so that' can be used before the verb'move' or'move' can be used after the preposition'so that'.<n>2)Since 'we-all' should come after the verb, the correct answer should include the noun 'people' after the verb and the preposition 'bedrooms' before the noun 'people'.<n>3)Only choice E does this: the choice that makes the most sense grammatically is option E.<n>So the final answe is E: house-move-we people-bedrooms<n><n>Input:Isn't it strange to believe the same myth or religion? It doesn't mention if the reception is for business or social reasons.<n>4. It explicitly says that a reception is required to be 'grand'.<n>5. Therefore, the context suggests that the reception is for societal reasons rather than for business.<n>6. Moreover, the reception is for a large number of people as is also implied.<n>7. Given these points, the large dining hall would be the best choice for holding a reception.<n>8. Since a reception cannot take place in a grand casino, a large room is not the best choice.<n>9. Similarly, a restaurant would be unsuitable because there is little room to host many people.<n>10. Therefore, C: restaurant is not the correct answer. Nor is A: grand casino. Nor B: large room.<n>11. Since the reception requires a large hall, it must take place in a country club.<n>12. A country club is the best choice given the context and the criteria for the choice of the reception venue.<n>13. Therefore, the only feasible answer choice is D: country club, which is the correct answer.<n>

Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n>Output:		1-The question is implying that Google Maps, street GPS services etc. have replaced the atlases of old.<n><n>2.This statement is incorrect. These services don't just replace the atlases but the entire map reading/navigation process.<n>3.To navigate using atlases, one must study and memorize the map. This is not the case in Google Maps where one merely has to put in the place they want to go to and the service will provide the best route to get there.<n>4.All of the other options are not possible because each option describes a single item.<n>5.There is more than one item for which the given options are applicable: map reading and navigation have been largely replaced/substituted by GPS services.<n><n>6. So, A: united states is the correct answer because it is the most direct and simplest description of the given option.<n><n>Input:He is not the kind of guy to do what? Choices: A: leave things hanging B: get involved C: make excuses D: get things done<n>Output:1. The words 'kind of guy' implies that the subject in the question is an individual.<n>2. Therefore, the question asks about him and his qualities, not those of a hypothetical person.<n>3.'Leaving things hanging' and 'getting involved' can mean different things to different people. <n>'Getting Excuses' means giving excuses for things which are not as serious, not that things are never done.<n>'Making Excuses' sounds like excuses about why things can't be done; not about why something wasn't done.<n>4.The use of different tenses in the other two options further confuses what kind of person the subject is.<n>5.From the context, it is evident that the person in question is a competent and determined man. Hence, D: get things done is the correct answer.<n>He 'gets things done' which means he will do what needs to be done. He is not the kind of person who will leave things hanging or get involved.<n>So the final Answer is D<n><n>Input: I have had numerous run ins with that particular gang over the years.  For example, I had the worst case of acne I had ever had while in grade 12 due to a fight that I had with a member of the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? E. river<n>Output: 1 and 2 are unrelated to waves but are about other topics. 3 is unrelated to waves but is about ripples. 4 and 5 are about water but are about water that cannot be considered rippled.<n>The answer is D: Ocean. Waves are connected to water and oceans is a type of water.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n>Output:		The question refers to a wife who was doing all the housework, indicating that she was performing a great deal of tedious and laborious housework.<n>1. The word 'anguish' refers to mental or emotional pain or suffering, suggesting that the wife was not happy with the situation and may have been experiencing some level of frustration or resentment towards her husband.<n>2. The word 'bitterness' also suggests that the wife may have been feeling resentful or angry about the fact that her husband was not helping with the housework or that he was not willing to participate in the cleaning or upkeep of the home.<n>3. The word 'tears' indicates that the wife was feeling overwhelmed by the amount of work she was doing, or that she was feeling frustrated or stressed by the situation.<n>4. The word'sadness' suggests that the fact that the wife was doing all the work was causing her to feel unhappy or down about the situation.<n>5. However, the most appropriate choice is D:tears which indicates that the wife felt overwhelmed, frustrated, or stressed by the amount of work and responsibility for the housework. <n>So the final answer in GATE CS 2015 Paper is D:tears<n><n>Input:What is the significance of the first part of the Bible which is titled as 'Genesis' except to indicate which one of the following? The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n>Output:		1.) In the first sentence, the word 'want' is followed by the word 'exotic snakes'.<n>2.) The second sentence states 'Too many people want [something]'.<n>3.) The third sentence says 'What to carry them?'. The first two sentences indicate that too many people want 'them' (exotic snakes). 'Them' (exotic snake) refers to the first subject of the sentence 'Too many people', and 'them' is plural.<n>4.) The subject of the sentence 'What to carry them?' is 'exotic snakes', not snakes in general. 'Carry' is then used as a metaphor for something more general, such as 'What to do with them?' or 'What to use them for?'.<n>5.) The best match for answer choices A: ditch and B: shop are 'them' and 'exotic'. However, 'what' and 'where' can be inferred from 'what to do with them?', 'where to sell them', and 'which shop to sell them in'. This means that B: shop is out of reach, and the correct answer is 'A:ditch'. <n>So the final answer A: ditch

Remember the question must be solved inside the function only.<n>(1)You are in a bank where you want to add an operation on another account but they ask you to write it as a single instruction. You are required to write a program to perform the requested adding operation. The syntax of the code should follow as if the program is to be written on a check or as a simple statement. It should be possible to run this operation through a single statement with the syntax as shown here. <n>Sample Output:<n>```python<n>1410<n>00<n>```<n>### Input:<n>Input: 142<n><n>(2) You want to buy some books from a store. The shop keeper gives you a price discount. He asks you to buy a total of 31 books of which you want to buy 15 books. Given a sum of discount you are required to find the maximum possible books you can buy.<n>```python<n>def max_books():<n>    book_cost = (142)<n>    books = (31)<n>    discount = (11)<n>    print(books, book_cost, discount)<n>    if books <= discount:<n>        for number in range(books):<n>            if number <= 15:<n>                print("Yes.")<n>            else:<n>                print("No.")<n>        return discount<n>    elif number <= 15 and number > discount:<n>        x = 1<n>        if x >= 1:<n>            for number in range(15):<n>                if number < x:<n>                    break<n>    else:<n>        x = number<n>``` <n>Output:<n>```python<n>31 142 11<n>No.<n>```<n>### Instruction : Write a Python program to implement a stack in the stackdata.zip file. <n>It need to

Choices:  A: demonstration B: garage C: building D: barn E: synagogue<n>Output:		Choosing your answer: Answer will be a combination of D and B.<n><n>1.The last sentence says that you can just imagine them talking to give a good what to you.<n><n>2. To avoid this the person has given him a good hand or in English'show' meaning she has given a good what to him.<n><n>5. The context clearly shows that there was no demonstration given so the correct answer is a combination of B (demonstration) and D (building).<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:Jim enjoyed killing people, but he did it too often and the cops found out.  What might the cops do to him? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n>Output:		1 & 2.The text suggests that Jim enjoys killing people.<n>3. However, he was caught and the cops found him out.<n>4. The cops had only two outcomes in mind, either take him to the jail or put him in prison.<n>5. It also suggests that Jim wouldn't get beaten up, died nor arrested.<n>6. Therefore the correct answers are:<n>B: going to prison, and D: getting arrested.<n>So the final answers are:<n>B, D

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:WHat do cats get into when they are ripping things apart? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n>Output:		The word 'things' indicates several individual objects are involved.<n>If we are talking about dogs' mouth, only one dog is mentioned by name. And since dogs in nature don't normally rip things apart, the option with "nature" is ruled out.<n>If we're talking about the garage, there is only one reference to a garage, not to multiple garages.<n>Based on context, "trouble" describes dogs getting in to cats; and "garage" describes a destination. Neither of these are applicable to cats getting into things -<n>Therefore the answer is: "ripping things apart."<n><n>Input: 1. This one is really a joke. Can I use this? 2. We'll see if it'll be funny. 3. Let me set that joke up for you. Choices:  A. Yes!  B. Well let try.  C. It's an excellent joke.  D. You cannot joke about that.  E. It's very funny.  F. It's not that funny. <n>Output: 1. The word "that" is referring to the joke.<n>2. The word "set" is referring to a joke or a story.<n>3. The word "you" is referring to a third person.<n>4. The word "try" indicates trying to make it work.<n>5. This sentence does use 'It' referring to the joke again.<n>"Well let try" cannot also be a question, so it must be either a command, an answer to a question or an exclamation.<n>It should also be obvious that a question mark is not needed. The sentence itself does imply a question.<n>Since it's not a question, that makes it a command-like construction.<n>Hence, " let try" cannot be an answer to a question.<n>Therefore, "Well let try" is command-like construction and can be inferred to be a command.<n>Hence E is the answer. Note that the question also does not ask you to guess if the joke is funny.<n><n>Input:  How can I get my kids to listen?  How to get kids to listen? Choices: 1. Don't tell them. 2. Tell them, but don't try to make them
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: anger B: not boredom C: stress D: boredom E: anxiety<n>Output:		<n>1. Given the context of the question, 'housework' suggests chores and tasks associated with maintaining a home.<n>2. This would include the dishes, laundry, tidying, etc.<n>3. These activities have the potential to engage your mind, body, and intellect.<n>4. The answer choices in the question are 'anger,' 'disgust,' 'feeling bored,''stress,' and feeling 'bored.'<n>5. None of these feelings are necessarily tied to doing housework, so the correct answer should be related to household chores or tasks.<n>6. The term that fits best is 'boredom' as boredom is a feeling that one has after repeatedly performing repetitive, unchallenging, or uninteresting tasks.<n>7. This feeling is common for people who are not very active as they perform their daily activities, and therefore, boredom is a natural response to performing household chores for long periods of time.<n>So the final answers are E.b,d are not related to performing household chores.<n>8. 'Boredom' is a proper answer because it fits in the context.

Choices:  A: injury B: death C: playing uno D: coma E: falling down<n>Output:		1) Firstly, this question refers to an event that happened to someone.<n> 2) the first half of the text ( Sky diving scared him once they jumped out...) refers to a specific event.<n> 3) This event involves someone who was involved in skydiving and lost consciousness.<n> 4) The second half of the text (while dying, playing cards... death coma falling down)  suggests that the person died or lost consciousness.<n>5) The words in this context suggest a 'playing card or 'death' which would be unrelated to injury or death, so it may be D or E or none of the mentioned words.<n>6) 'coma' describes the state of someone who has lost consciousness and is in a deep sleep and unable to wake up or respond to stimuli and so may be D or E.<n> 7) 'dying or death' is unlikely to be involved as it doesn't fit in with the topic of the event.<n><n>Input: My husband, the most loving and kind of men, he's so cute. He took a bullet for me once.  It was the what? Choices: A: most violent B: best part C: easiest part D: easiest hit E: most fatal part<n>Output:<n><n>### Reference: <n>https://leetcode.com/problems/most-common-word-in-a-string/<n>https://leet.codes/problems/more-and-most-interview-question/<n>https://leettalk.medium.com/find-the-most-common-prefix-in-a-sentence-2b2ee82817d5<n>https://leetfor.com/2018/03/most-common-prefix/
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Nowadays, we still call travelling by that name which is derived from the name of that particular voyage. Hence, Traveling is the answer and it must be the correct choice.<n><n>

Write the next line, which should continue the story. <n><n>Input: You can lead a horse to water but a pencil must be lead.<n>Output: They must try harder if they expect to succeed.<n>Explanation: We know that a pencil must have a lead but a horse can drink water. A horse to water means that a horse can be led to water, while a pencil must lead must be lead. A pencil needs a lead but a horse does not need to be led to water. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n>Output:		First, the question implies that money is likely to be stolen.<n>The text suggests that one response to such a situation would be to be angry about it as money is likely to be an important or valued possession.<n>Given this context, the option A: complete sentence can be ruled out from among all other choices. It's also likely that a person is more likely to cross the street upon being robbed than to drink tea as he will likely be angry.<n>Based on this information, drinking tea is unlikely to be the response to money being stolen. Hence option D can be eliminated.<n>Similarly, option B: feel angry can also be eliminated as anger is more likely than drinking tea.<n>Option C: cross street does not seem a logical conclusion as he is more likely to be angry and possibly cross the road than to drink tea. Hence it is also eliminated from the list of options.<n>From the given information, C: cross street, B: feel angry and D: drink tea can be eliminated. And the final answer is E: park.<n><n>Input:The thief was on the run through the city. Choices:  A cross B the street  C drink Coffee  D drive the car  E park the car<n>Output: First,the text suggests that the thief can also be the person who is trying to escape from the authorities.<n>Also it is implied that he is the person who committed the crime.<n>Secondly, the text implies that he is attempting to escape by using a car.<n>Thirdly, the text suggests that the thieves were running through the city and that 'thief' is the correct grammatically correct form of 'he' in this context.<n>Taking into consideration the above information, the option A cross the street is incorrect.<n>B: was in a hurry is correct as it has implied all previous elements and cannot be contradicted by the given text.<n>D: drove through the city clearly suggests that the criminal attempted to escape from the city driving through it. Again contradicting the text.<n>E: parked himself the car is also correct as the thief is trying to hide his identity and is trying to escape. Hence option D: drove the car is incorrect.<n>Hence the final answer will be B: drive through the city.<n><n>Input:John only gave a perfunctoral examination of the corp,
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n>Output:		This sentence is quite difficult to understand. Here are some tips: 1. The sentences uses the word 'extra strong' to indicate that it is strong enough to be used for other purposes.<n>2. However, the sentences adds a qualifier - what? - suggesting that we are examining an exception(extra strong) rather than the ordinary case(normal glass).<n>3. 'What?' is most commonly used to ask for more information about the 'extra strong' glass.<n>4. Using our previous examples, we can surmise that: 1. To be forceless means that something is easily broken. 2. To be regular means that something is common.<n>5. Based on this, 'extra strong' glass seems weak/fragile (to be broken) instead of strong/forceless (to stand firm).<n>6. Therefore, B: fragile is the correct answer. It is forcelessness/weakness that is referred to by the 'extra strong' qualifier.<n>

Choices:  A) a high position B) a long period of time C) a short period of time D) a small number E) several people<n>OutPut:The answer is C) a short period.When you consider that the word fourteen means fourteen years, you would assume that the answer is B. If this had been the case, it would not be likely that she would be a woman.<n><n>## Second Question<n>Input: The president, a man well-known for his personal kindness, signed a bill. Choices: 1. B) a private person 2. D) a public person 3. B) a warm person 4. A) a public bill 5. A) an important bill<n>OutPut: The answer is B, A kind person would likely sign a private or a kind bill. The president was praised for being a kind person and he would sign a kind bill for such.<n><n>#3:<n>## First Question:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n>Output:		The word'mighty' is an exaggeration of how the camper felt. The text does not suggest that he felt small, insubstantial, helpless or stupid. Although unimportant and insignificant would be accurate descriptors of the camper's state of mind, they are not sufficient to answer the question.<n><n>So the final answer can be any which is not C: stellar which is not D: somewhat which is not E: helpless. Hence it is A: unimportant<n><n>Input:We have been in the forest for far too long. Everyone has been feeling somewhat what? Choices: A: uneasy B: frail C: hungry D: tired E: restless<n>Output: The word "frail" is grammatically incorrect. Although hungry, tired, or restless can also describe the campers feelings, they do not directly contradict the adjective "feeling" in the prompt.<n><n>So the correct answer would be B: feeling frail which is grammatically incorrect so the answer is not A: uneasy which is contradictory to feeling frail

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. Choices:  A: liquidated B: own resources C: branch out D: commit crime E: game over<n>Output:		<n>1. A company is liquidated when it is declared bankrupt.<n>2. A company can own its own resources or those it rents until enough of those resources become part of their inventory and/or stock of assets to declare bankruptcy.<n>3. If a company's liquidation results from a crime, it can be fined or shut down.<n>4. A company can branch out by expanding or diversifying its operations to include other goods or services.<n>5. Once it is declared bankrupt, a company plays no games anymore.<n>6. None of these things happen to a bankrupt company, rather they are things a company can do while not bankrupt.<n>7. Therefore, B: own resources is the correct answer.

However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What would a document be if it is not obtuse? Choices:  A: pointed B: bright C: easy D: clear E: acute angled<n>Output:		1) From the context, the document is intended for non-experts of the area that it is describing.<n>2) The word 'obtuse' suggests that the document is inaccurate or unclear. Therefore, any document is not obtuse.<n>3) The question asks what a document is if it 'is not obtuse', and the answer must be 'Not obtuse', thus A: not obtuse is the correct answer.<n><n>Input:A ploy is a plan or trick used to achieve a goal, especially a devious or unethical one. Some writers even say a ploy's goal is often sinister. Choices: A: A B: C C: D D: E<n>Output: 1: A: An objective is the result of a goal.<n>2: The question asks for the correct choice between the two sentences. Although the goal of the plan or tricks is 'to achieve a goal', as suggested, the plan or trick is not necessarily 'devious or unethical' as the second sentence suggests.<n>3: A: To be 'devious/unethical' is specific meaning, and the plan or trick is usually not explicitly stated as 'devious or un-ethical'.<n>4: Therefore, B: 'Is often Sinister' could be construed as an adjective to describe the objective of a plan or trick.<n>5: The sentence suggests that deception or trick for the purpose of evil/sin is often the objective of the goal.<n>6: The best answer would be the word that is 'often the objective of the goal.'<n>7: Considering the meaning of'sinister' that we have mentioned above, and a plan or trick 'devisive' or 'evil in nature' would lead to 'achieving a goal'. This would mean that a ploy 'is often sinister'.<n>8: 'Often sinister' is the best answer that makes sense of the context. Choices:  C: by sound E: by smell B: by sight D: by touch A: by feeling<n>Output: 1) The question asks us to determine the most likely way, and'musician' is not the opposite of 'non-musician'.<n>2) In fact, they both do music.<n>3) By this logic, the non-musician is still a person who has not practiced music, and perhaps even someone who dislikes music.<n>4) The text does not include any words that directly reference a feeling or touch. However, it is not logical to assume that everyone who likes music can hear music, so by this logic, there may be some way of distinguishing between people who have musical talent and those who do not.<n>5) The most likely way of determining this would be through hearing or sight. One could even guess that a musician might be the best, as they have more talents that a non-musician (and thus, someone who dislikes or is incapable of music should not be considered a musician). Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n>Output:		A: The children shouting loudly in the middle of the queue caused Bob and Boris to face 'frustration'. Being annoyed in the middle of the line is also a possibility. But, 'irritation', 'out of order' and 'delays' are not applicable.<n>If it was the person shouting loudly then it would have been irritation or out of order. But 'the line' cannot be 'out of order'. So if the queue was fast, then the children had nothing to do for a long time in the queue. That would cause 'delays'. Finally, there are many possible reasons for 'delays'. But what the sentence gives is just 'fast'. So we can't say anything for 'delays'. So the final answer is A: frustration. It doesn't make sense to say "the only book written for somebody" or "somebody has written the only book for somebody".<n>Choice D is wrong because the subject, 'book' cannot be a direct object.<n>So the correct choice must be C

In this question I marked the answer as 'D', 'the green field'.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:The turkey needed to be kept from spoiling, what is useful in this situation? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:what is the goal of going jogging? Input: <n><n>Every Saturday morning, the farmers would go into town for market.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question below:<n><n>Input: Every Saturday morning, the farmer would go into town for farmer's market.  Choices A & B: farmer & farmers are wrong.  Choice C: town is wrong, too.  Choice D is also wrong.  Choice E is the correct answer.<n>Output: 1) "Go into town for farmer´s market" means that the farmer will go to the town in order to participate in the market, not simply to visit.<n>2) "Every Saturday morning, the...will go into town for market" means that every Saturday, the farmers will go into town for market (not vice versa).<n>3) "Every Saturday morning..." must be followed by a complement: the event will happen "to" or "by" somebody (who is one of the farmers).<n>4) "For market" is a dative complement. "To market" would be wrong, since markets are where farmers usually sell their products.<n>5) "Every Saturday morning" is a universal time phrase. There is no need of any other time phrase.<n>6) "Every Saturday morning", "the farmers", "to go" are coordinating phrases since "every Saturday morning" is introduced by the universal time phrase "every Saturday morning", which coordinates with it.<n>7) "The farmers" is the subject of the sentence and coordinated with "for market". As for the second coordinate "will go...", its

Choices:  A: desire B: spending money C: money D: needs E: time<n>Output:		Because the word 'to have' is the third person singular, the subjective pronoun 'You' takes the subjective form 'Your'.<n>The subjective pronoun is also in the present tense.<n>From here, it can be inferred that the answer will be 'desire','spending money', or 'time', all of which are nouns and involve the action of 'having'.<n>However, neither the question nor the context suggests that the individual is lacking in any of these things.<n>Therefore, 'desire','money', or 'time' cannot be the missing element.<n>In this context, the missing element is the subjective pronoun, which takes the form 'You need', not 'You need to have to buy.'<n>Therefore, the final answer is D. You need.<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:Where might you have cake with your ice cream? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n>Output:		1) When professionals are involved, the outcome of the sport depends not just on their ability, but also on their level of physical fitness.<n>2) Playing sports for long periods of time and competing would therefore tire the players, which would impair their ability to work.<n>3) Sweat, dirt, and rain are not reasons for their inability to compete since they are not causes of discomfort or injury.<n>4) Being overheated during the game would not affect their gameplay, as they are well trained to keep themselves cool during intense physical activity(unless they haven't had enough breaks or water).<n>5) There is no mention of injuries, which are a cause for concern when playing a sport. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:John's RV needs electricity so that he can cook lunch. The given context is that he wants to cook lunch.<n><n>1.  The provided answer choices do not mention electricity at all.<n>2.  Thus we can eliminate A: toy store, B: basement, C: school.<n>3. John would not want to go to the basement where he lives to get electricity, either, nor would he go to the toy store to get electricity.<n>6. He's not planning to plug in his R.V. at a building.<n>7.  We can also cross out E since it's a location that John wouldn't go to to get electricity.  All answer choices have to fit the context.<n>8. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What is not a safe way to transport jewelry on vacation? Choices:  A: suitcase B: department store C: safe deposit box D: these twos are not safe way to transport jewellery E: lady's boudoir<n>Output:		The answer is E: lady's boudior. Firstly, suitcase is used in the context of transporting an object rather than an item, so there must be more than one way to transport jewels safely.<n>Secondly, department store also implies more than one possible way, so is not an appropriate choice.<n><n>Next, safe deposit box is implied to be too large for transporting jewels safely and not an answer.<n><n>Finally, safe implies security, so is not a safe or recommended method for transporting jewelry.<n><n>Therefore, the suggested method 'lady's boudoir' fits the context:<n><n>1. It implies something where you keep valuables safely and is also a single object.<n>2. It is a place to keep items, so is also an appropriate choice for transporting jewellery safely.<n>3. Lastly, 'boudoir' implies a place where women go to be alone and to unwind; it also has a romantic association, which suggests jewellery would fit well there; and the romantic aspect gives the impression that the place is likely to be looked after.<n><n>Therefore the answer is E: lady’s boudior which implies a place where women keep their valuables and also can be referred to as a place for women to relax and unwind, which is most likely to be well looked after by the occupant.<n><n>So the final answer to the question is E: lady' s boudoir<n><n>Input: You can't teach an old dog new tricks, but you can always teach a puppy new tricks. Choices:  A:(old dog) B: (puppy) C: (no dog) D: (old dog) never E: (puppy) never<n>Output: The answer to the question is D: (old dog).<n><n>Firstly, the question states that you can't teach old dogs new tricks but can always teach a puppet new tricks.<n><n>Secondly, 'can' implies an action that can take place, so the two parts of this statement both support the idea that you can't make a 'puppy' learn new tricks.<n>Firstly, a dog is old when it is no longer a pup.<n><n>In context, an old dog implies the equivalent of a young dog and puppy implies the equivalent

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The use of 'him' here does not suggest otherwise<n>2: 'Already' has the double meaning that the speaker has already met 'him'. We should interpret these two meanings in two different directions: either the speaker already met 'him' and Jack or Jack himself is 'him'<n>3: From context, the speaker has not met Jack. Using the definition of 'Yet' that the speaker has not met him yet implies that he is yet to meet him. Therefore, the speaker has not come across Jack, so the correct answer is D.<n><n>Input: Have you ever seen him play? Choices:  A: tide pool B: beach sand C: tidepools D: current E: cooking pot<n>Output:		1)Tide pool: Nope. Not even remotely related to what the crab was struggling with.<n>2)Beach sand: Nope. Not at all. The text never says or indicates that the problem with the crab is sand.<n>3)Tidepools: Nope. Not relevant in this context.<n>4)Current: Close. As crabs do struggle against currents, but the current is not an impeding factor in this case.<n><n>5)Cooking pot: Nopers. The crab was the victim of over cooking not of a pot of water<n><n>So the correct option is E: over cooking<n><n>Input:  The cat was stalking the mouse.The mouse was cowed. Why?  Choices:  a)The mouse was starved.b)The mouse was trapped.c)The mouse was afraid.  d)The cat was afraid of the mouse.  e)The cat was not able to do the cat stuff.<n>Output: 1-The text didn't mention a word about mouse food so starved is not the correct option.<n><n>2. Trapped: Nope! Mice don't generally get trapped in their cages and therefore, trapped will not have anything to do with the mouse feeling cowed.<n>3-Cowed: Nopers! The context here is about the mouse being too afraid to do anything while surrounded by the cat. This means that the cat was not afraid of the mouse and cannot be cowed by the mouse.<n><n>So correct option is d: cat was not able to cat stuff<n><n>Input:  They were not to be trusted, for they were only in it for themselves.Their self centeredness left everybody in despair. It is true that a speech therapist will help you with these, but a speech therapist also helps you to have more confidence in the way you talk.  Furthermore, a speech therapist can help you to understand how and why people's speech is produced the way it is. These abilities are referred to as having "good speech intelligibility." One important skill for speech intelligibility is called using "good prosody."<n>So the final answer C: give speeches is incorrect

It suggests that you are uncomfortable as you stumble into the kitchen and may even be grumbling before you are awake.<n>When you grunt, you may say it is in discomfort, but it is not from discomfort alone.<n>4.) Finally, given this context, 'grunt' means that you mutter something, indicating that the gas is likely already running when you start cooking.<n>5.) The final answer is B: the stove is already running<n>So the final answer  is B: the stov is already running<n><n>Input: He wanted a nice thick slice of roast beef with mushrooms and Yorkshire pudding, of course, and a big bowl of baked potatoes.<n>Output: The 'Baked potatoes' are unlikely to be found 'in the cold room'. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n>Output:		<n><n>The text states that the temperature is changing rapidly and then states that it is beginning to heat up and this is in contrast to the previous statement that the sun is out and the temperature is changing rapidly, it states that the temperature is beginning to cool down, thus answer choice B is incorrect because it says the temperature is increasing.<n>Answer choice E is incorrect, it says the temperature is beginning to heat up, however the sentence that follows states that the temperature is cooling down, therefore the temperature can't be rapidly heating up while simultaneously cooling down.<n>Answer choices A and C does not make sense. <n>The sun is out and the temp is changing rapidly; now the sun is out and temperature is cooling down; therefore the temperature must be cooling down rapidly.<n>Therefore the only choices are A and D.<n><n>Input:He was the happiest person I knew I didn't know how he could ever get that way, but he had a what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: grocery store B: nightstand C: armpits D: own bathroom E: medicine chest<n>Output:		D: own bathroom<n>In other words, the sentence implies that the woman asked him to look in his own bathroom first, implying that she thought he would be more likely to check there first. So we choose D: own bathroom as the final answer<n><n>## Solution<n>### (Solution 1)<n><n>```python <n>import os<n>import spacy<n>import tensorflow as tf<n><n>dev_id = "spacy_model_dev"<n>os.makedirs(f'/models/{dev_id}', exist_ok=True)<n>tokenizer = spacy.load(f'/models/raw/{dev_id}/{dev_id}_tokenizer-de-raw.json')<n>model = spacy.load("/models/raw/{dev}_{dev_id}_model-de-raw.npz", allow_zip_data=True)<n>model.to(174_001 # gpu) <n><n>## Load data<n>df = tf.data.Dataset.from_tensor_slices(<n>    [[item for item in spacy_answer]<n>      for spacy_answer in [<n>        [['intricate'], 'E'], [-2, -3], [tf.constant(27.5)]<n>      ]])<n>input_examples = df.map(lambda x: spacy.util.get_spacy_doc(x, return_begin_end=True))<n>    input_texts = list(input_examples)<n><n>## Prepare model <n>doc = spacy.blank('de_core_news_md')<n>for item in input_texts:<n>    doc.update(item)<n><n>ans = {}<n>for item in input, ij in doc:<n>    if len(item.ents) == 1:<n>        ans[item.span.start:item.span.start+item.ent_idx+1] = item.head<n>```<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Choices:  A. full B: some C: much D: every E: none of these<n>Output: The text says that the book was "full of facts, and yet not full of truth".<n><n>1. Full means "all of something", while truth means "the actual reality of something".<n>2. Therefore, the book was apparently not full of all of the facts or the actual reality of something.<n>3. To determine which item in the list is not completely factual enough, one must compare truth to every option except none of these.<n><n>4. In this context, "every" and "full" cannot be in conflict, and must both be wrong.<n><n>5. In this case, the only choice which is inconsistent with "full" is D because having "some", "much", or "every" or "many" would imply that the facts are enough. The book is not full of truth.<n><n>Input: The man said in answer, "I think this means that a house can be built so that it will have neither drafts nor heat, which is unnatural and therefore bad." The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What is a place that could have tens of thousands of fiddle? Choices:  A: tennessee B: band practice C: orchestra D: violin case E: music store<n>Output:		What is a place that could contain tens of thousands of fiddle, that is, could have that many things in a container? 1. The words "fiddle" and "tense" are used. 2. The word "tense" occurs only in the phrase "tense orchestra". 3. The phrase "could have" suggests a place (tense orchestra) could contain a large (fiddle) number of objects (tense). 4. For the grammatical structure, that is, the verb that can be replaced by "could have", "could" is the perfect continuous form of "could", "could" is used in "would have". 5. The word "ten" does not relate to "fiddle" in the grammatical structure. 6. The word "orchestra" in the grammatrical structure can be replaced by a word beginning with the letter "o", which is a part of the answer choices. 7. Therefore, C: orchestras is the best answer.<n><n>So the final answer has already been answered by the above two examples<n><n>The solution is C)  ORCHESTRAS<n>

Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n>Output:		A) Obtuse means narrow or pointed. Something that isn't obtuse must, in order to not be obtuse, be anything but narrow or pointed. Angles that are obtuse is a possibility here. But angles aren't the only things that can be considered "bright" or "correct". "Correct" could also be referred to as something with "accuracy, precision, or completeness"<n>B) All of these choices exclude "obtuse"<n>C) The word "obtuse" comes from the Latin word "obtusus" which means "narrow or pointed" but also means "having a slight or barely perceptible edge" and "blunt". <n>D) Angles that are obtusely angled is a possibility here. <n>E) Again, angles aren't the the only thing that can be referred to as "clear". It is possible that you could say "the road is now clear" but it is unlikely that the word "clear" will be used as a synonym for "obtuse".<n>So the final answer should be E: Clear<n><n>Input: What is the difference between prose and verse?<n><n>Output:In general, the difference between prose is the difference between a poem and a story. Poems and stories express ideas, emotions, and observations by organizing words. This is the key to prose. It's the only difference in what they express, and how they are expressed. Poems, on the other hand, are meant to look easy to read. They are easy to understand. What makes poetry different is how it looks.<n><n><n><n>

He needed his doctor to empathize with him as a person, see him as more than a name or a diagnosis

He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n>Output:		1: The text implies satisfaction.  What might a satisfied person do after being satisfied? Choices  A: board ship. Though it may be difficult to imagine a ship, in the era of steamships, they did not need much maintenance.<n>2: Grocery shop- It would be impossible to grocery shop more. It is more likely to cross the street. 3: Feel happy. Feeling happy is quite possible, considering that being satisfied is also a possibility.  Feeling sad would be impossible.<n>4: Cross Street - This would be possible, but it wouldn't go with the idea of being satisfied.<n>5: Shout at - This is impossible, as the only thing that's possible is feeling happy. <n>6: Therefore, A: board ship is the correct answer. It may be a difficult connection to make, but the satisfied person may use the money and board a ship.<n><n><n><n>### Instruction:Answer the two questions below.<n><n>Input: Which of the following is a nonsensical sentence? Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n>Output:		1 The question begins with what planet is the Atlantic Ocean part of?<n>2 The question is clearly asking for where the Atlantic Ocean is located (either on another planet or on Earth) not a specific feature of the Atlantic Ocean like its basin, submarines, etc.<n>3 The answer is therefore either a, e or d.<n>4 Since the question says that the Atlantic Ocean is in its own planet, the answer must be A (planet). <n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:A beaver builds structures to block what sort of feature? Next, the question asks for the name of the feature the beaver is blocking out, and it's a body of water, thus pointing to the correct answer as choice A: Body of water.<n>So the final conclusion is A: Body of water

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:Rumors of roving bands of monsters killing people could lead to what? Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n>Output:		1) The text suggests that rumors of monsters are killing people is causing people to react emotionally and irrationally, so we can infer that the panic and mass hysteria options are likely incorrect answers.<n>2) The text doesn't suggest any actions that can lead to getting in trouble, so that option is likely incorrect.<n>3) The text does not use the term "murder", but rather "killing people". In fact, only the murder option suggests that the deaths are being caused intentionally, or on purpose.<n>4) The text does not suggest that monsters are being killed on purpose, so getting in trouble is unlikely.<n>5) The text doesn's discuss any criminal behavior, so you can rule out going to prison and murder.<n>6) Therefore, the correct answer is B: getting in trouble<n><n>Input: It's impossible to describe what it means to be a friend to someone who's angry all the time. Choices:  A. impossible to grasp B. impossible to grasp a hold of C. impossible to describe D. impossible to catch E. impossible to know<n>Output: 1.) The word "grasp" is used in the text to describe how a friend of someone who's angry would interact with their friend. The other options involve "grasping" a hold of something the text doesn't describe, "grasping" information, or catching someone, a feat that is clearly not possible with a person who is constantly angry, especially with the usage of the verb "grasp". Therefore, we can eliminate "impossible to grasp" and "impossible to grasp a hold of".<n>2.) "Impossible to describe" is not appropriate, because the phrase " It's impossible to know" and/or "impossible to understand" might fit, as they both imply the author's inability to express himself.<n>3.) "Impossible to catch" is also incorrect, for the same reason why "impossible to grasp the hold" is incorrect, mentioned in #1.<n>4.) Finally, "impossible to know" is a better fit. This phrasing implies a level of difficulty that's impossible to surpass, or a lack of knowledge, both of which fit the subject of the sentence. Therefore, the correct answer, as seen in the answer key, is "impossible to know".<n>So the final answer would be

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Output: 1. First, the question suggests that John did everything that was required of him while examining the corpse.<n>2. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:What would something be if you do not need it? Choices:  A: satisfied B: unnecessary C: luxury D: sufficient E: extra<n>Output:		1: Satisfied here means happy or as expected. That is not what'something' is. It is an 'object' with certain use, need and value. Hence, in this sense B: unnecessary is more appropriate if we do not want them. <n>2: 'Use' has different meaning from 'use value'. The thing is 'use value' is necessary whereas the thing is 'use'. So, in this situation, if we do not want 'any' object, this choice is a good one.<n>3: But, if we want to be specific and avoid having unnecessary things, we can have only required things. Luxury means extra; an extra thing, extra things. I think the only suitable choice is C:luxury.<n>4: At the end, we do not want anything with exception for any necessity. So, D: sufficient is good since both satisfied and D are good answers.<n>So the final answers are:<n>A: B/C/D<n>B: E<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him. The text also suggests that despite doing everything that was required, he still missed the real cause of death.<n>3. Given this context, John's examination was not lacking in care, thought, completeness, or intricacy as these are not necessarily related to missing information.<n>4. However, the examination missing the real cause of death suggests that it wasn't comprehensive or detailed enough.<n>5. In this context, being 'thorough' implies that he would have taken more time to carefully check every aspect of the examination.<n>6. Therefore, D: thorough is the correct answer. The missing element in John's examination was thoroughness. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n>Output:		1) The question suggests that secular parties take place with some regularity.<n>2) For the secular party to take place, there must be a crowd, which would not likely happen if it were only held at the time of death of members of the household.<n>3) Therefore, the parties would likely be frequent.<n>4) This implies that they cannot be held just before death or at any other frequent point in time as then, the time period available for hosting parties would be limited, leaving little time to prepare guests.<n>5) Since the parties usually involve food, it would be a tedious task to prepare the ingredients when they have limited time, or the food has to be pre-cooked and frozen and then re-heated.<n>6) Since these parties occur with some regularity, the time period must have been well planned for, in advance, and the ingredients have to be bought in advance (not just at the short notice that would occur if the party takes place upon the death of a member of household).<n>7) The party has to be eternal, since, if it is held at the time of certain death of people (after all people are always going to die at some point in their life), it will only continue in the memories of the family.<n>8) Given that these parties take place at frequent intervals and are eternal because they happen at death, they cannot be held at the death of a person.<n>9) Therefore, the time period at which they are held must be unpredictable.<n><n>So the correct choice is E: unpredictable.<n>

However, the sentence does not specify how often or how long she sings.<n>2. She could sing everyday for half an hour or 8 hours a day for a week or a month.<n>3. Singing doesn't seem to be bothering anyone, so the first two options are out.<n><n>4. Since she hasn't given other reasons for her singing, we can rule out that either of the other choices are her motive for singing so much.<n>5. She is clearly enjoying herself, which suggests that either she has a good voice or that inhaling her singing is enjoyable.<n>6. But it is unlikely that she inhales her singing, so that is out.<n>7. So it boils down that she sings very often just for the fun of it.<n>8. Had he been more thorough, he would have discovered the real cause of death.<n>So the final answer is D: thorough<n><n>Input:This city in Northern Norway is filled within things to do like Polar Nights half marathons and located in the middle of the Northern lights oval, which city is it? Choices:  A: northern B: nome C: tromsø D: finnmark E: vadsø<n>Output:		Finally, I have used wordnet to obtain a lexical database consisting of over 130000 words.<n>I will use this lexical database to extract feature vectors from the text.<n>However, the number of word vectors can range between 30000 and 80000.<n>I therefore use a sliding window of size two to extract word vectors from the texts.<n>I then compare the two vectors to check the consonants' similarity between the two sentences.<n>I will use the cosine similarity measure to find the nearest neighbors to input the text.<n>Output:My goal at this stage is to determine the sentiment of each token in the corpus.<n>The goal is to determine not just the overall sentiment of the text, but the sentiment of each token.<n>However, due to the difficulty of this task, the token-level sentiment has not been determined.<n>Therefore, I only consider the corpus level sentiment rather than the token-level sentiment.<n>Output:The current architecture can be broken down into four steps: 1. I used an open-source sentiment analysis API to first obtain sentiment scores for each document in my corpora.<n>2. I used that sentiment scores to extract the polarity of the corpus using a sliding window with a width of <n>5 of the text's length.<n>3. I used a sliding window consisting of five sentences each to evaluate the documents' sentiment.<n>The window size can also be used to determine the document level average sentiment score.<n>I used the TF-IDF method to calculate the number of times each word appears in a document and the total corpus size.<n><n>Output:I then trained a machine learning model to predict the sentiment of each document based on their word usage.<n>I used this model as the input of a recurrent neural network.<n>The neural network's output was the sentiment score of the input text, while the hidden layer was used to determine the sentiment of the word-level data.<n>The network's architecture can be seen in the figure below.<n>I trained this machine learning model by using a support vector machine and k-means clustering to label the training data.<n>I then used the models' weights (i.e. the number of training examples) I used the training data and the model of the sentiment of the word vectors.<n>This model allowed me to determine the sentiment of any given word

Choices:  A: gain experience B: taking notes C: listen carefully D: complete test E: focus<n>Output:		1: The student wants the professor to say what he means and wants to understand the meaning of his words.<n>2: Taking notes is a way of recording the information the professor presents, but it is not necessarily listening, as one may miss out on important information while trying to write.<n>3: Listening carefully is an important part of understanding meaning but it does not ensure that the student will be able to answer all the questions in his or her next test.<n>4: The student cannot "complete" any test as tests vary in nature. For instance, a student may take an in-class test to assess the knowledge of students in the classroom rather than testing the completion of another paper.<n>5: "Focus" does not always equate to listening to what a speaker is saying. There may be multiple distractions like discussions, sneezing, coughing (if social distancing protocols are not followed) to name a few.<n>6: Therefore, E: focus is the correct answer. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.
